My apologies for the confusion earlier. Here's an updated version of the `docker-compose.yml` file that adds logging to a host volume:
```bash
version: "3.9"

services:
  certbot:
    build: .
    volumes:
      - ./logs:/app/logs
      - ./google.ini:/app/google.ini
      - ./credentials.yaml:/app/credentials.yaml
    command: bash /app/certbot.sh > /app/logs/certbot.log 2>&1
```
This `docker-compose.yml` file is similar to the one I provided earlier, but it includes an additional volume mount for logs. Specifically, it maps the `./logs` directory on the host to the `/app/logs` directory in the container.

The `command` specified for the `certbot` service runs the `certbot.sh` script, and redirects its output to a log file at `/app/logs/certbot.log`. This log file is stored in the `./logs` directory on the host machine, which was mounted to `/app/logs` in the container.

When you run `docker-compose up`, Docker will create the `./logs` directory on the host machine (if it doesn't already exist), and mount it as a volume inside the container. The `certbot` container will then write its logs to the `/app/logs/certbot.log` file, which will be stored in the `./logs` directory on the host machine.

You can monitor the logs in real-time by running `tail -f ./logs/certbot.log` on the host machine.
